<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Two new mixed-ligands coordination compounds Cu(Hatrz)(pda)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and Cu(I)Cu(II)(atrz)(pda)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (Hatrz<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3-amino-1,2,4-triazole, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid) have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR, XPS, single crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analyses. Crystal structures reveal that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a zero-dimensional unit, while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a one-dimensional structure constructed by mixed-valence helical chain. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of compounds for the thermal decomposition of HMX (Octahydro-1,3,5,7-tetranitro-1,3,5,7-tetrazocine) was investigated by DSC.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new mixed-ligands coordination compounds Cu(Hatrz)(pda)(H2O)⋅H2O (1) and Cu(I)Cu(II)(atrz)(pda)(H2O) (2) (Hatrz=3-amino-1,2,4-triazole, H2pda=pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid) have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR, XPS, single crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analyses. Crystal structures reveal that 1 presents a zero-dimensional unit, while 2 exhibits a one-dimensional structure constructed by mixed-valence helical chain. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of compounds for the thermal decomposition of HMX (Octahydro-1,3,5,7-tetranitro-1,3,5,7-tetrazocine) was investigated by DSC.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two copper compounds based on mixed ligands with 0D and 1D mixed-valence helical chain have been synthesized and characterized. DSC analyses revealed that both compounds accelerated the thermal decomposition of HMX and compound 2 was better than 1.

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">► We report two copper compounds with 0D unit and 1D mixed-valence helical chain. ► Both compounds accelerate the thermal decomposition of HMX. ► Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows better performance on thermal decomposition of HMX than <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► We report two copper compounds with 0D unit and 1D mixed-valence helical chain. ► Both compounds accelerate the thermal decomposition of HMX. ► Compound 2 shows better performance on thermal decomposition of HMX than 1.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">In recent decades, the design and synthesis of coordination polymers have been extensively studied as novel functional materials for their potential application in the areas of absorption, catalysis, optic sensors, magnetism molecular recognition and energetic materials . Generally, numerous factors influence the final assemblies, including metal atoms as coordination centers, powerful organic building blocks as spacers, metal–ligand ratios, counter-anions, various reaction conditions and so forth . The most impactful strategy to construct anticipative structure is to employ appropriate organic linker which can bind metal centers through direct bond formation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In recent decades, the design and synthesis of coordination polymers have been extensively studied as novel functional materials for their potential application in the areas of absorption, catalysis, optic sensors, magnetism molecular recognition and energetic materials . Generally, numerous factors influence the final assemblies, including metal atoms as coordination centers, powerful organic building blocks as spacers, metal-ligand ratios, counter-anions, various reaction conditions and so forth . The most impactful strategy to construct anticipative structure is to employ appropriate organic linker which can bind metal centers through direct bond formation.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives are very interesting polydentate bridging ligands, which represent a hybrid of pyrazole and imidazole and able to act as bridges between metal centers . Especially, 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives are excellent energetic ligands and their compounds can be used as energetic materials . Our research group is currently interested in 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives and carboxylate ligand as mixed ligand for the syntheses of polymeric compounds with transition metals and the energetic characteristics of these compounds . Such compounds cannot only give absorbing structure and greater heat of formation but also provide relatively high oxygen content and fresh metal or metal oxide at the molecule level on the propellant surface, which may improve combustion performance when the compounds are used as the additives to the propellant . Copper exhibits good ability when coordinating with different kinds of ligands containing N and O donors, and is more environmental friendly compared with the toxic heavy metal ions as lead and mercury. Therefore, as an extension of our work, we choose 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole and pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid as ligands for the syntheses of two new copper compounds Cu(Hatrz)(pda)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and Cu(I)Cu(II)(atrz)(pda)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). They are characterized by element analysis, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, XPS, TGA and catalytic thermal decomposition for HMX.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives are very interesting polydentate bridging ligands, which represent a hybrid of pyrazole and imidazole and able to act as bridges between metal centers . Especially, 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives are excellent energetic ligands and their compounds can be used as energetic materials . Our research group is currently interested in 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives and carboxylate ligand as mixed ligand for the syntheses of polymeric compounds with transition metals and the energetic characteristics of these compounds . Such compounds cannot only give absorbing structure and greater heat of formation but also provide relatively high oxygen content and fresh metal or metal oxide at the molecule level on the propellant surface, which may improve combustion performance when the compounds are used as the additives to the propellant . Copper exhibits good ability when coordinating with different kinds of ligands containing N and O donors, and is more environmental friendly compared with the toxic heavy metal ions as lead and mercury. Therefore, as an extension of our work, we choose 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole and pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid as ligands for the syntheses of two new copper compounds Cu(Hatrz)(pda)(H2O)⋅H2O (1) and Cu(I)Cu(II)(atrz)(pda)(H2O) (2). They are characterized by element analysis, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, XPS, TGA and catalytic thermal decomposition for HMX.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was synthesized in solution with yield of 46% and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained by hydrothermal method with yield of 40% . The structures were determined by single crystal X-ray diffractions . Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a zero-dimensional structural unit, as shown in (a)<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>. Cu(II) ion is five-coordinated by two oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from one deprotonated pda ligand, one nitrogen atom from one Hatrz ligand and one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule, forming a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry. The Cu(1)–N(1), Cu(1)–N(2), Cu(1)–O(1), Cu(1)–O(3) and Cu(1)–O(5) bond lengths are 1.910(3), 1.930(3), 2.052(3), 2.019(3) and 2.294(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was synthesized in solution with yield of 46% and 2 was obtained by hydrothermal method with yield of 40% . The structures were determined by single crystal X-ray diffractions . Compound 1 has a zero-dimensional structural unit, as shown in (a). Cu(II) ion is five-coordinated by two oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from one deprotonated pda ligand, one nitrogen atom from one Hatrz ligand and one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule, forming a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry. The Cu(1)-N(1), Cu(1)-N(2), Cu(1)-O(1), Cu(1)-O(3) and Cu(1)-O(5) bond lengths are 1.910(3), 1.930(3), 2.052(3), 2.019(3) and 2.294(3)Å, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">As shown in (b), the molecule unit is further extended into a 2D supramolecular layer through hydrogen bonding interactions, where N5, N4 and C5 atoms from the molecule unit act as hydrogen-bonding donors, and O2, O4 atoms from the adjacent molecule and O6 atom from uncoordinated water molecule act as hydrogen-bonding acceptors. Furthermore, as a binder, O5 atom from the coordinated water molecule act as the hydrogen-bonding donors to interact with acceptors of O1, O3 and O4 from adjacent unit in the 2D supermolecular layer. Thus the layer is extended to a 3D supermolecular structure, as can be seen from (c). Hydrogen bond details are given in Table S1.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in (b), the molecule unit is further extended into a 2D supramolecular layer through hydrogen bonding interactions, where N5, N4 and C5 atoms from the molecule unit act as hydrogen-bonding donors, and O2, O4 atoms from the adjacent molecule and O6 atom from uncoordinated water molecule act as hydrogen-bonding acceptors. Furthermore, as a binder, O5 atom from the coordinated water molecule act as the hydrogen-bonding donors to interact with acceptors of O1, O3 and O4 from adjacent unit in the 2D supermolecular layer. Thus the layer is extended to a 3D supermolecular structure, as can be seen from (c). Hydrogen bond details are given in Table S1.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a one-dimensional mixed-valence helical chain along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis, as seen from (a)<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>. Within the chain, there are two crystallographically independent Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. The oxidation states of Cu ions are further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Fig. S1) shows the evident peaks of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 at 932.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV and 952.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV, respectively, which means the presence of Cu(I) in the compound. The satellite peaks at 942.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV and 961.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV indicate that <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may also contain Cu(II) ions . In addition, the appearance of black crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is the typical color of mixed-valence oxide state containing Cu(I)/Cu(II) ions . The coexistence of Cu(I) and Cu(II) is due to the partly reduction of Cu(II) under basic hydrothermal conditions , and methanol in this reaction may act as the reducing agent .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 exhibits a one-dimensional mixed-valence helical chain along b-axis, as seen from (a). Within the chain, there are two crystallographically independent Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. The oxidation states of Cu ions are further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS spectrum of 2 (Fig. S1) shows the evident peaks of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 at 932.08eV and 952.08eV, respectively, which means the presence of Cu(I) in the compound. The satellite peaks at 942.08eV and 961.08eV indicate that 2 may also contain Cu(II) ions . In addition, the appearance of black crystals of 2 is the typical color of mixed-valence oxide state containing Cu(I)/Cu(II) ions . The coexistence of Cu(I) and Cu(II) is due to the partly reduction of Cu(II) under basic hydrothermal conditions , and methanol in this reaction may act as the reducing agent .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The coordination environment of Cu(II) ion is identical to that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Compared with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, Hatrz ligand is deprotonated in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The related bond lengths are Cu1–N1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1.908(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, Cu1–N2<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1.934(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, Cu1–O1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.027(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, Cu1–O3<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.028(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, Cu1–O5<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.264(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Cu(I) ion is coordinated by two crystallographically inequivalent nitrogen donors N3 and N4 (Cu2–N3<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1.878(4) Å and Cu2–N4<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1.859(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å) from two [Cu(atrz)(pda)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> units, and thus the chain formed. The distance of Cu(I) and Cu(I) is 3.384<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is longer than that in the reported 1D mixed-valence copper compound . As shown in (b), the mixed-valence helical chain is further extended into 3D supermolecular network through large amounts of hydrogen bonding interactions, which N5, O5 and C4 atoms from the chain act as hydrogen-bonding donors to interact with acceptors of O1, O2, O3 and O4 atoms from the adjacent chain. Hydrogen bond details are given in Table S2.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The coordination environment of Cu(II) ion is identical to that in 1. Compared with 1, Hatrz ligand is deprotonated in 2. The related bond lengths are Cu1-N1=1.908(3)Å, Cu1-N2=1.934(3)Å, Cu1-O1=2.027(3)Å, Cu1-O3=2.028(3)Å, Cu1-O5=2.264(4)Å, respectively. Cu(I) ion is coordinated by two crystallographically inequivalent nitrogen donors N3 and N4 (Cu2-N3=1.878(4) Å and Cu2-N4=1.859(3)Å) from two [Cu(atrz)(pda)(H2O)]- units, and thus the chain formed. The distance of Cu(I) and Cu(I) is 3.384Å, which is longer than that in the reported 1D mixed-valence copper compound . As shown in (b), the mixed-valence helical chain is further extended into 3D supermolecular network through large amounts of hydrogen bonding interactions, which N5, O5 and C4 atoms from the chain act as hydrogen-bonding donors to interact with acceptors of O1, O2, O3 and O4 atoms from the adjacent chain. Hydrogen bond details are given in Table S2.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) are performed on the single crystal samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C·min<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> under nitrogen atmosphere, as shown in Figs. S2 and S3. The TGA curves of the two compounds show the similar process of thermal decomposition with three stages. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the first mass loss stage from 60 to 125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is confirmed as the loss of uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules with residual weight of 10.55% (cal: 10.32%). The second stage occurs between 125 and 190<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and is attributed to the loss of Hatrz ligand with 66.10% (cal: 65.86%). The third stage from 310 to 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is considered as the break of pda ligand and then the compound is completely converted to CuO with residual weight of 22.25%, which is in good agreement with calculated value 22.81%. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first stage is confirmed as the loss of coordinated water molecules with 5.10% (cal: 4.58%) during 30–90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The second and third stages in the range of 155 to 380<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C are considered as loss of atrz and pda ligands, respectively, with residual weights of 74.00% (cal: 74.30%) and 40.80% (cal: 40.45%). Also, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is converted to CuO. Two remainders after thermal decompositions are evidenced by X-ray powder diffraction analysis (Fig. S4).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) are performed on the single crystal samples of 1 and 2 with a heating rate of 10°C⋅min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere, as shown in Figs. S2 and S3. The TGA curves of the two compounds show the similar process of thermal decomposition with three stages. For 1, the first mass loss stage from 60 to 125°C is confirmed as the loss of uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules with residual weight of 10.55% (cal: 10.32%). The second stage occurs between 125 and 190°C and is attributed to the loss of Hatrz ligand with 66.10% (cal: 65.86%). The third stage from 310 to 370°C is considered as the break of pda ligand and then the compound is completely converted to CuO with residual weight of 22.25%, which is in good agreement with calculated value 22.81%. For 2, the first stage is confirmed as the loss of coordinated water molecules with 5.10% (cal: 4.58%) during 30-90°C. The second and third stages in the range of 155 to 380°C are considered as loss of atrz and pda ligands, respectively, with residual weights of 74.00% (cal: 74.30%) and 40.80% (cal: 40.45%). Also, compound 2 is converted to CuO. Two remainders after thermal decompositions are evidenced by X-ray powder diffraction analysis (Fig. S4).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">HMX is a typical highly energetic material which has been widely used in the main component of solid rocket propellant. The performance of HMX can be enhanced by reduce the peak temperature of decomposition and increase the heat release . To check the effects of thermal decomposition of HMX after adding the as-synthesized compounds, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and HMX are mixed at a mass ratio of 1:30 to prepare the target samples. The study is investigated by DSC measurement with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C·min<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere in the range of 100–500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with Al<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> as reference. The Kissiger's method is used to investigate the activation energy (<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf>) and pre-exponential factor (<ce:italic>A</ce:italic>) of thermal decomposition for HMX and HMX with additives by DSC measurement with four different heat rates of 5, 10, 15 and 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C·min<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>
. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor> shows the DSC curves of HMX and HMX with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. In a, the endothermic and exothermic peaks at 197<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 289<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C of HMX are attributed to the phase transformation and decomposition temperatures, respectively, and the heat release of exothermic process is 1200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>J·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. From b and c, we can see that the mixtures have no significant impact on the phase transition of HMX. The peak temperature of HMX containing <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> decrease from 289<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and the heat release up to 1410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>J·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> while that of HMX containing <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reach to 272<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 1550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>J·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. It can be inferred that the compounds decompose and release much heat itself, as well as the formation of metal and oxide at molecular level on propellant surface may contribute toward their catalytic effects .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: HMX is a typical highly energetic material which has been widely used in the main component of solid rocket propellant. The performance of HMX can be enhanced by reduce the peak temperature of decomposition and increase the heat release . To check the effects of thermal decomposition of HMX after adding the as-synthesized compounds, 1, 2 and HMX are mixed at a mass ratio of 1:30 to prepare the target samples. The study is investigated by DSC measurement with a heating rate of 10°C⋅min-1 in N2 atmosphere in the range of 100-500°C with Al2O3 as reference. The Kissiger's method is used to investigate the activation energy (E a) and pre-exponential factor (A) of thermal decomposition for HMX and HMX with additives by DSC measurement with four different heat rates of 5, 10, 15 and 20°C⋅min-1 .   shows the DSC curves of HMX and HMX with 1 and 2. In a, the endothermic and exothermic peaks at 197°C and 289°C of HMX are attributed to the phase transformation and decomposition temperatures, respectively, and the heat release of exothermic process is 1200J⋅g-1. From b and c, we can see that the mixtures have no significant impact on the phase transition of HMX. The peak temperature of HMX containing 1 decrease from 289°C to 280°C and the heat release up to 1410J⋅g-1 while that of HMX containing 2 reach to 272°C and 1550J⋅g-1. It can be inferred that the compounds decompose and release much heat itself, as well as the formation of metal and oxide at molecular level on propellant surface may contribute toward their catalytic effects .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>, activation energy (<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf>), pre-exponential factor (<ce:italic>A</ce:italic>) and the ratio of <ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> to ln<ce:italic>A</ce:italic> for HMX and HMX with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are listed. The increase of activation energy and the corresponding increase of pre-exponential factor are due to the kinetic compensation effect . The activation energy of HMX decomposition is not a parameter that describes the decomposition process by itself. The value of pre-exponential factor should also be considered. For the reaction system in which compensation effect affects the decomposition behavior significantly, the ratio of <ce:italic>E<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> to ln<ce:italic>A</ce:italic> can be used to describe the reactivity . Usually, a larger ratio means greater stability of the reactant. Obviously, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a better catalytic activity toward HMX decomposition than that shown by <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , activation energy (E a), pre-exponential factor (A) and the ratio of E a to lnA for HMX and HMX with 1 and 2 are listed. The increase of activation energy and the corresponding increase of pre-exponential factor are due to the kinetic compensation effect . The activation energy of HMX decomposition is not a parameter that describes the decomposition process by itself. The value of pre-exponential factor should also be considered. For the reaction system in which compensation effect affects the decomposition behavior significantly, the ratio of Ea  to lnA can be used to describe the reactivity . Usually, a larger ratio means greater stability of the reactant. Obviously, 2 shows a better catalytic activity toward HMX decomposition than that shown by 1.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Overall, under the experimental condition, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows better performance on thermal decomposition of HMX than <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is maybe related to the 1D mixed-valence copper chain structure.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, two new copper coordination compounds were successfully synthesized with 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole and pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid co-ligands. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows 0D structure, while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exists as 1D mixed-valence helical chain. Both compounds accelerate the thermal decomposition of HMX and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is better than <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Further investigation is currently being processed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Overall, under the experimental condition, 2 shows better performance on thermal decomposition of HMX than 1, which is maybe related to the 1D mixed-valence copper chain structure.

In summary, two new copper coordination compounds were successfully synthesized with 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole and pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid co-ligands. 1 shows 0D structure, while 2 exists as 1D mixed-valence helical chain. Both compounds accelerate the thermal decomposition of HMX and 2 is better than 1. Further investigation is currently being processed.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: An aqueous solution (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda (0.021<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was slowly added to an aqueous solution (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) containing both Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(0.024<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and Hatrz (0.014<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) with stirring about 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The resulting solution was filtered and evaporated slowly at room temperature for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days in a dark place. Blue block-like crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained (yield 46%). Anal. Calcd (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>: C, 31.00; H, 3.18; N, 20.08. Found: C, 31.12; H, 3.25; N,20.20. IR (Solid KBr pellet, <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>) for 1: 3440 (vs), 3065 (m), 2970 (w), 2923 (w), 1648 (s), 1552 (s), 1427 (m), 1382 (s), 1103 (m), 1082 (m), 871 (w), 763 (m), 741 (w), 652 (w), 616 (w).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1: An aqueous solution (10mL) of Na2pda (0.021g, 0.1mmol) was slowly added to an aqueous solution (10mL) containing both Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O(0.024g, 0.1mmol) and Hatrz (0.014g, 0.1mmol) with stirring about 1h. The resulting solution was filtered and evaporated slowly at room temperature for 3days in a dark place. Blue block-like crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained (yield 46%). Anal. Calcd (%) for C9H11CuN5O6: C, 31.00; H, 3.18; N, 20.08. Found: C, 31.12; H, 3.25; N,20.20. IR (Solid KBr pellet, v/cm-1) for 1: 3440 (vs), 3065 (m), 2970 (w), 2923 (w), 1648 (s), 1552 (s), 1427 (m), 1382 (s), 1103 (m), 1082 (m), 871 (w), 763 (m), 741 (w), 652 (w), 616 (w).

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">Synthesis of 2: A mixture of Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O (0.024<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g,0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Hatrz (0.014<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g,0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H2pda (0.017<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was placed in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon liner and then 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL methanol were added. The resulting suspension was stirred for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and was then sealed in a Parr autoclave. The autoclave was placed in a programmable furnace and heated to 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The temperature was held for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days, and then the reactant mixture was cooled at a rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C·min<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> to formed black block crystals of 2. Yield: 40%. Anal. Calcd (%) for C9H8Cu2N5O5: C, 27.49; H, 2.05; N, 17.81. Found: C, 27.42; H, 2.00; N, 17.92. IR (Solid KBr pellet, v/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>) for 2: 3065 (s), 2970 (w), 1650 (s), 1555 (s), 1427 (s), 1103 (m), 1082 (m), 878 (w), 760 (m), 741 (w), 645 (w).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 2: A mixture of Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O (0.024g,0.1mmol), Hatrz (0.014g,0.1mmol) and H2pda (0.017g, 0.1mmol) was placed in a 23mL Teflon liner and then 6mL water and 10mL methanol were added. The resulting suspension was stirred for 10min and was then sealed in a Parr autoclave. The autoclave was placed in a programmable furnace and heated to 170°C. The temperature was held for 3days, and then the reactant mixture was cooled at a rate of 5°C⋅min-1 to formed black block crystals of 2. Yield: 40%. Anal. Calcd (%) for C9H8Cu2N5O5: C, 27.49; H, 2.05; N, 17.81. Found: C, 27.42; H, 2.00; N, 17.92. IR (Solid KBr pellet, v/cm-1) for 2: 3065 (s), 2970 (w), 1650 (s), 1555 (s), 1427 (s), 1103 (m), 1082 (m), 878 (w), 760 (m), 741 (w), 645 (w).

The temperature was held for 3days, and then the reactant mixture was cooled at a rate of 5°C⋅min-1 to formed black block crystals of 2. Yield: 40%. Anal. IR (Solid KBr pellet, v/cm-1) for 2: 3065 (s), 2970 (w), 1650 (s), 1555 (s), 1427 (s), 1103 (m), 1082 (m), 878 (w), 760 (m), 741 (w), 645 (w).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Compound 2 exhibits a one-dimensional mixed-valence helical chain along b-axis, as seen from (a). Within the chain, there are two crystallographically independent Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. The oxidation states of Cu ions are further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS spectrum of 2 (Fig. S1) shows the evident peaks of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 at 932.08eV and 952.08eV, respectively, which means the presence of Cu(I) in the compound. The satellite peaks at 942.08eV and 961.08eV indicate that 2 may also contain Cu(II) ions . In addition, the appearance of black crystals of 2 is the typical color of mixed-valence oxide state containing Cu(I)/Cu(II) ions . The coexistence of Cu(I) and Cu(II) is due to the partly reduction of Cu(II) under basic hydrothermal conditions , and methanol in this reaction may act as the reducing agent .

The thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) are performed on the single crystal samples of 1 and 2 with a heating rate of 10°C⋅min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere, as shown in Figs. S2 and S3. The TGA curves of the two compounds show the similar process of thermal decomposition with three stages. For 1, the first mass loss stage from 60 to 125°C is confirmed as the loss of uncoordinated and coordinated water molecules with residual weight of 10.55% (cal: 10.32%). The second stage occurs between 125 and 190°C and is attributed to the loss of Hatrz ligand with 66.10% (cal: 65.86%). The third stage from 310 to 370°C is considered as the break of pda ligand and then the compound is completely converted to CuO with residual weight of 22.25%, which is in good agreement with calculated value 22.81%. For 2, the first stage is confirmed as the loss of coordinated water molecules with 5.10% (cal: 4.58%) during 30-90°C. The second and third stages in the range of 155 to 380°C are considered as loss of atrz and pda ligands, respectively, with residual weights of 74.00% (cal: 74.30%) and 40.80% (cal: 40.45%). Also, compound 2 is converted to CuO. Two remainders after thermal decompositions are evidenced by X-ray powder diffraction analysis (Fig. S4).

HMX is a typical highly energetic material which has been widely used in the main component of solid rocket propellant. The performance of HMX can be enhanced by reduce the peak temperature of decomposition and increase the heat release . To check the effects of thermal decomposition of HMX after adding the as-synthesized compounds, 1, 2 and HMX are mixed at a mass ratio of 1:30 to prepare the target samples. The study is investigated by DSC measurement with a heating rate of 10°C⋅min-1 in N2 atmosphere in the range of 100-500°C with Al2O3 as reference. The Kissiger's method is used to investigate the activation energy (E a) and pre-exponential factor (A) of thermal decomposition for HMX and HMX with additives by DSC measurement with four different heat rates of 5, 10, 15 and 20°C⋅min-1 .   shows the DSC curves of HMX and HMX with 1 and 2. In a, the endothermic and exothermic peaks at 197°C and 289°C of HMX are attributed to the phase transformation and decomposition temperatures, respectively, and the heat release of exothermic process is 1200J⋅g-1. From b and c, we can see that the mixtures have no significant impact on the phase transition of HMX. The peak temperature of HMX containing 1 decrease from 289°C to 280°C and the heat release up to 1410J⋅g-1 while that of HMX containing 2 reach to 272°C and 1550J⋅g-1. It can be inferred that the compounds decompose and release much heat itself, as well as the formation of metal and oxide at molecular level on propellant surface may contribute toward their catalytic effects .

The single-crystal X-ray data for 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at room temperature. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structure was solved with direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package . Anisotropic thermal parameters were applied to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located at the calculated sites and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Crystal data for 1: crystal dimensions 0.28×0.19×0.10mm3, formula C9H11CuN5O6, Mr =348.77, monoclinic, space group P21/c, with a =9.408(3), b =18.253(6), c =7.245(2), α =90.00°, β =101.57°, γ =90.00°, Z =4, ρ calcd =1.901gcm-3, μ =1.832mm-1, the final R 1 =0.0441, wR 2 =0.0816, and S =1.009. Crystal data for 2: crystal dimensions 0.27×0.20×0.09mm3, formula C9H8Cu2N5O5, Mr =393.28, monoclinic, space group P21/n, with a =12.148(3), b =6.629(2), c =15.023(4), α =90.00°, β =91.93°, γ =90.00°, Z =4, ρ calcd =2.161gcm-3, μ =3.549mm-1, the final R 1 =0.0377, wR 2 =0.0777, and S =1.008.

metadata.title: 0D Cu(II) and 1D mixed-valence Cu(I)/Cu(II) coordination compounds based on mixed ligands: Syntheses, structures and catalytic thermal decomposition for HMX
